Title.evidence: We therefore wished to compare the outcome of patellofemoral arthroplasty (PFA) with TKA in a blinded randomized controlled trial.

Trial_Design.evidence: One hundred patients were included from 2007 to 2014 and were randomized to PFA or TKA.

Participants.evidence: Patients were eligible if they had debilitating symptoms and isolated patellofemoral disease.

Objective.evidence: We therefore wished to compare the outcome of patellofemoral arthroplasty (PFA) with TKA in a blinded randomized controlled trial.

Method_Outcome.evidence: SF-36 bodily pain was the primary outcome.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomized to PFA or TKA (blinded for the first year; blinded to patient, therapists, primary care physicians, etc; quasiblinded to assessor).

Blinding.evidence: blinded to patient, therapists, primary care physicians, etc; quasiblinded to assessor.

Number_Randomised.evidence: One hundred patients were included from 2007 to 2014 and were randomized to PFA or TKA.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Four percent (two of 50) of patients died within the first 2 years in the PFA group (none in the TKA group), and 2% (one of 50) became ill and declined further participation after 1 year in the PFA group (none in the TKA group).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The area under the curve (AUC) up to 2 years for SF-36 bodily pain of patients undergoing PFA and those undergoing TKA was 9.2 (SD 4.3) and 6.5 (SD 4.5) months, respectively (p = 0.008).

Harms.evidence: There was no difference in the number of complications.
